entry.title: PO Subtotal Mismatch in Ariba — Request to Fix via Adjusted NetAmount
entry.content:
Dear All,

We’re currently facing an issue where the Subtotal values in Ariba PO line items do not match the ERP PO due to Ariba only receiving Quantity and Unit Price — without any discounts or the actual NetAmount.

Is it possible to send the net amount of each item to Ariba under the Subtotal section? If so, could you please advise on how this can be achieved?"

 

Alternatively, if there is another process you prefer, please let us know.

Thank you for your assistance.

Example

ERP Net Amount = 133,310.73

 

Ariba Subtotal = 133,310.00

entry.title: SAP Open Source Webinar: Neutral Governance for the Gardener Project
entry.content:
Did you know that Gardener, SAP’s open-source solution for managing Kubernetes clusters at scale, has entered a new chapter? It is now governed under the NeoNephos Foundation, part of Linux Foundation Europe — a move that strengthens its long-term sustainability and aligns it with the EU’s Important Project of Common European Interest – Next Generation Cloud Infrastructure and Services (IPCEI-CIS). This probably sounds like a lot. If you’re interested in learning more about Gardener and how it fits into such an initiative, then... 

  

Join us on September 24th at 3:00 pm CEST / 6:30 pm IST to learn what this change means, how Gardener works under the hood, and why it matters for the future of cloud infrastructure in Europe and beyond. Marc Vornetran, Software Engineer, and Niclas Moldenhauer, Engineering Manager, will also talk about Gardener’s features, recent developments, and give live demos. 

Register link: SAP Sign Up

entry.title: Consolidated subcontracting PR for multiple production orders
entry.content:
The requirement is for Production Order operation subcontracting. We have seen the standard SAP operation subcontracting process. In this, one of the operations in the Routing is performed by the external vendor (subcontractor). In SAP for each operation, based on the master data maintained, system will generate a Subcontracting Purchase Requisition. So, there will be one PR each production order.

 

The client requirement is that there should be only one subcontracting Purchase Requisition created for the several production orders combined.   

 

Is there any solution for the requirement?

entry.title: Re: Launch IW51 Service Notification in S4 Customer Engag...
entry.content:
@HRISHIKESH6868 wrote:

In Current landscape We are using functionality of CS Notification creation from CRM Web UI ( CRM EHP 7.3). For this WEB UI ISUSERVNOTIF has been used.

Does the same feature/ Functionality available in S4 Customer Engagement? OR Transaction Launcher is the only option to launch IW51 transaction in Web Ui?

 

In SAP S/4HANA Customer Engagement, the same functionality for creating customer service notifications that existed in CRM EHP 7.3 using the ISUSERVNOTIF component is generally not available in the same way. SAP S/4HANA Customer Engagement is a simplified version of SAP CRM, which is embedded directly into S/4HANA. While it uses the same underlying CRM Web UI framework, the standard processes have been updated and streamlined. Transaction Launcher is a key feature in S/4HANA Customer Engagement, and it's commonly used to launch older SAP GUI transactions like IW51 from the Web UI. Therefore, while you can still create service notifications, it's often done through different, more modern processes or by using Transaction Launcher to access the classic IW51 transaction.

entry.title: ChatGPT Meets SAP Analytics Cloud: A Developer’s Guide to ChatGPT Custom Widget
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful platform for data analytics, planning, and predictive insights. Enhancing SAC with AI-driven conversational capabilities can significantly improve user interaction and data exploration. The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC enables seamless integration of OpenAI's ChatGPT chat box directly into your SAC stories and analytic applications, providing a flexible, fast, and customizable chat interface. This blog walks you through the features, installation, and usage of the ChatGPT Custom Widget, empowering you to leverage AI-powered conversational analytics within SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

What is the ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC?

The ChatGPT Custom Widget is a ready-to-use component that embeds a ChatGPT-powered chat box inside your SAC environment. It allows users to interact with data and analytics through natural language queries, enhancing the decision-making process with AI-generated insights.

📥Download Links: ChatGPT Custom Widget: https://sap-custom-widget.rohitchouhan.com/?dl=ChatGPT
🔗GitHub Repository: https://github.com/SAP-Custom-Widget/ChatGPT
📚Documentation: chatgpt-custom-widget-documentation.pdf 

Key Features and Capabilities:

  • 100% Free to Use (needs OpenAI API key)
  • Modern Chat Interface: WhatsApp/Messenger-style design
  • Multiple AI Models: GPT-3.5-turbo, GPT-4, GPT-4-turbo support
  • Advanced Parameters: Temperature (0-2), max tokens (1-4096), response choices (1-10)
  • Custom Styling: Colors, fonts, sizes, themes
  • Real-time Responses: Streaming text generation
  • Export Chat:  Conversation export
  • Error Handling: Built-in API error management
  • Auto-updates: Widget version notifications
  • Mobile Responsive: Works on tablets and phones

Installation Guide

Follow these simple steps to add the ChatGPT Custom Widget to your SAP Analytics Cloud environment:

  1. Download the Widget JSON File
    Obtain the ChatGPT.json file from the official GitHub repository or the provided link.
  2. Access SAC Custom Widgets
    Log in to your SAC portal. Navigate to Stories from the left sidebar, then select the Custom Widget tab.
  3. Upload the Widget
    Click the + icon on the right side and upload the downloaded ChatGPT.json file.
  4. Ready to Use
    The widget is now available for use in your SAC stories and analytic applications.

Complete Guidance and Tutorial Video

If you want to see how to use and install what are the feature, please follow this video to know it better.

Configuration and Usage

  1. Get OpenAI API Key
    Visit platform.openai.com → Sign up/Login → Go to API Keys → Create new key → Copy and save securely
  2. Add Widget to Story
    Open your SAC story → Insert → Custom Widget → Select "ChatGPT Widget" → Drag to canvas
  3. Configure API Settings
    Designer Panel → Builder → API Configuration:
    • API Key: Paste your OpenAI key
    • Model: Choose gpt-3.5-turbo (fast, cheap) or gpt-4 (better quality)
    • Temperature: 0.1 (focused) to 1.5 (creative)
    • Max Tokens: 150-2048 (response length)
    • System Message: Set AI behavior and context
  4. Customize Appearance
    Design tab →  Styles, header text
  5. Test and Deploy
    Preview mode → Test chat functionality → Save story → Share with users

Advanced Use Cases and Applications

Business Intelligence Applications:

  • Data Exploration: "Show me sales trends for Q4" or "What are the top performing products?"
  • Report Generation: Auto-create executive summaries from dashboard data
  • Anomaly Detection: Ask AI to identify unusual patterns in data
  • KPI Analysis: Get explanations for metric changes and recommendations

Industry-Specific Applications:

  • Customer Service: Automate FAQ responses, provide product recommendations, handle basic inquiries
  • Sales & Marketing: Lead qualification, campaign analysis, customer segmentation insights
  • Finance: Budget variance analysis, financial report explanations, cost optimization suggestions
  • Operations: Process optimization, resource allocation, performance monitoring
  • HR Analytics: Employee satisfaction analysis, recruitment insights, performance reviews

Integrating ChatGPT with SAC transforms your analytics environment into an interactive, AI-powered assistant that enhances productivity and decision-making.

Security Considerations:

  • API Key Protection: Never share or hardcode API keys
  • Data Privacy: Be cautious with sensitive business data in prompts
  • Rate Limiting: Monitor API usage to avoid quota limits
  • Access Control: Restrict widget access to authorized users only
  • Regular Updates: Keep widget updated for security patches

Conclusion

The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAP Analytics Cloud is a game-changer for organizations looking to infuse AI-driven conversational intelligence into their analytics workflows. With easy installation, flexible customization, and powerful OpenAI integration, this widget empowers users to interact naturally with their data and unlock deeper insights.

Get started today by downloading the widget, setting up your OpenAI API key, and embedding the chat box into your SAC stories. Experience the future of analytics with ChatGPT and SAP Analytics Cloud!

If you want to explore the widget further or contribute, check out the GitHub repository maintained by the developer Rohit Chouhan.

entry.title: Dangerous Goods Packing Instructions in Product Compliance
entry.content:
Every year more than 1.25 million dangerous goods shipments are transported by air. With air cargo growth predicted at 4.9% every year over the next 5 years the number of dangerous goods shipments will rise significantly. With so many dangerous goods being shipped by air, safety regulations must be followed precisely. IATA helps identify the risks and works with ICAO (International Civil Aviation Organization) to amend the regulations providing stakeholders with the most current guidelines on how to handle and ship dangerous goods safely. 

One of the data points we have been working on improving and expanding are the Packing Instructions for dangerous goods. We start out on the launchpad and go to the Manage Compliance Requirements Dangerous Goods.  

 From here we can see all the newly updated compliance requirement versions and we are going to choose IATA. IATA’s Dangerous Goods Regulation Manual (DGR) contains a list of approximately 3,000 articles and substances that are commonly shipped by air. We can see the new Packing Instructions and that we have over 2,300 already as part of the system for you to use.

But that is just an overview, in the View Regulatory Data app we can search for a specific UN number, in this case 1090 and see the applicable IATA enclosure-specific data sets along with the hazard label. In this app, you have packing instruction information for both single and combination packaging.

Now we can check the specific code and see the combination packaging info along with any additional requirements. For hazmat to be shipped by air, there are specific procedures to be met. First, the shipper must meet their criteria, such as declaring the shipment as dangerous goods, properly completing the Dangerous Goods Declaration, and adequately preparing the shipment for transport.

 

From an IATA publication we can see that packaging requirements of all types are a top priority when transporting dangerous goods. Safety is job number one when transporting dangerous goods, with SAP S/4HANA for product compliance we aim to make it easier and faster for you to get your products where they need to be.

More specific information on available packing instructions can be found here. 

More information on Dangerous Goods Content can be found here.

entry.title: Re: EXTERNAL JOIN when using temporary tables
entry.content: Hello Don, thank you for your response. I am afraid there has been a misunderstanding, sorry for that. I have lots of reports that print from tables that are created as GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE in the database. The "Database Expert" does not show this type of table. To add such a table to a report, I rename the original table in the database and create a persistent table with the same structure and access rights. After adding this table to the report, I can restore the original GLOBAL TEMPROARY TABLE and use it in the designer as usual. In this scenario, the described effect occurs as soon as a "Verify Database" is performed.

entry.title: ABAP GEN AI: Accessing LLM Capabilities within ABAP-Stack using ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM-Part 2
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, we successfully established ISLM connectivity in S/4 Hana Public cloud and able to call it using ABAP AI SDK. With this connectivity in place, we’re now ready to build our own custom use case.

  • Customer Requirement: Whenever a Sales Order is rejected, the system should automatically trigger a custom notification E-Mail to the respective Sold-To Party (Customer) informing them about the rejection. Since customers may belong to different regions, it is essential that this E-Mail communication is sent in the Sold-To Party's preferred language.
  • GAP: S/4 Public Cloud does not provide any feature yet to maintain, access & translate E-Mail contents for CUSTOM business scenario.
  • High Level Solution Proposal: ABAP GENAI-Powered Solution using ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management). 

High-Level Architecture for ISLM custom AI scenario  

 

Solution Overview --

Step-1) Creating Intelligent Scenario and Models for our use case.

Create Intelligent Scenario in ADT -->

 

Once Intelligent Scenario is created, Create the intelligent scenario model on top of the above scenario.

In the intelligent model, provide the below information.

  • Intelligent Scenario name which we have created in first step
  • Large language Model Name and its version
  • Model prompts templates (pre-written prompt structure where variables or placeholders will be filled to generate consistent and accurate responses from the AI model.)

Two User prompt has been created for the custom use case -

Note --> For demonstration purposes, we have created two separate user prompts for the custom use case. However, this task can also be accomplished with a single prompt.

1) Prompt-1 -Translating E-mail body from source language to target language.

Prompt used --> 

Task: Convert the following E-Mail body string {ISLM_EMAILBODY} into {ISLM_LANGUAGE} language, preserving all HTML tags as-is present in the body.
Response Expectation:
Return only the translated E-Mail body string in the response.

2) Prompt-2 - Replacing the placeholders from E-mail body with actual sales order data.

Task:
Replace the placeholders in the given E-Mail body ({ISLM_EMAILBODY}) with actual runtime values provided in ISLM variables.

Replacement Rules:

Replace ##Salesorder## with {ISLM_SALESORDER}

Replace ##SalesOrderItem## with {ISLM_SALESORDERITEM}

Replace ##Material## with {ISLM_MATERIAL}

Replace ##ReasonRejection## with {ISLM_REASONREJECTION}

Data Format Notes:

{ISLM_SALESORDERITEM}, {ISLM_MATERIAL}, and {ISLM_REASONREJECTION} may contain multiple values, separated by commas (,).

For multiple Sales Order items, output each record on a new line in the following format:
{SalesOrderItem1}, {Material1}, {ReasonRejection1}
{SalesOrderItem2}, {Material2}, {ReasonRejection2}
...and so on.

Response Expectation:
Return only the Final converted E-Mail body string after all placeholders have been dynamically replaced. No additional text or explanation is needed.

Intelligent Scenario Management App

Published Intelligent Scenarios will be visible here in Intelligent Scenario Management App

 

 

You can select the Scenario and deploy it.

 

Step -2) Creating custom Fiori App for storing E-Mail-template in source language.

Custom Fiori App has been created which will be used by Business users/ Functional to maintain E-Mail-Body in source language. (Just like we do in standard Fiori App - Maintain E-mail templates). This will be one time activity which need to be done by functional.

Since this was only a POC, we created a simple RAP-based application to store the e-mail body. In a real scenario, this application could be replaced with a freestyle UI5 application, or the template can be stored in DMS.

Source E-mail content translated to multiple target languages --> 

User can create translation to new language by clicking on create and by just providing target language. In the background ISLM will translate all the E-mail content from source language to target language.

In the above screenshot we are creating a new E-mail body in Hindi target language (ISLM will translate all the content from English to Hindi).

All the content has been successfully translated into Hindi language, except for the two items listed below. Additionally, users have the option to manually update any content in case of incorrect word translations.

  • HTML tags --> This will be used while sending the mail.
  •  Placeholders like ##SalesOrderItem## , ##Material## , ##ReasonRejection## , these values will be replaced by ISLM in runtime by the actual Sales order data while sending the mail.

The application also provides a built-in mechanism to retrigger an E-Mail in the desired target language. Users can select the required E-Mail template and initiate the 'Send Mail using AI Template' action. Upon doing so, the system will prompt the user to enter the following details:

  • Sales Order Number
  • Target Template Language

An E-Mail is generated in the selected target language, populated with the actual Sales Order values.

Now the first step of storing the default E-mail template in source language is completed. 

Step - 3) Creating local event for Sales order -> Create Event

A local event will be triggered automatically whenever a new Sales Order is created. Within this event, custom logic can be implemented to utilize ISLM for translating the E-Mail body based on the Sold-to Party's language and to send the translated E-Mail to the user.

a) Fetch the Sold-to Party's language (this will be the target language for the translation).

b) Once we have the target language, we will be using ABAP AI SDK to translate E-Mail body to target language using "fetch_store_email_template" 

  • Instantiate the factory via class CL_AIC_ISLM_COMPL_API_FACTORY and method GET. Use the factory method CREATE_INSTANCE which provides you with a new instance of the completion API. Provide the intelligent scenario name which we have created in step1 as this carries the information about the connection and the model. 
  • Create the message container which will be used to hold system and user prompt.

 

 

  • Fetch the target language, then pass both the language and the e-mail content to be translated as prompt parameters defined during the creation of the intelligent scenario. 

 

ISLM-Variables in prompt 1--> 

  • Use EXECUTE_FOR_MESSAGES to provide the prompt as a message list wrapped in a message container instance. Each message is classified as system role, user message, or assistant message. You can get an instance of the message container using the method CREATE_MESSAGE_CONTAINER. 
  • Execute method will be called to get the response of the LLM as a string 

Lv_emailstringtarget will hold the E-mail body in target language with placeholder, now the next step will be to remove the place holders from the E-MAIL body with actual Sales Order data.

For example --> 

Replacing the place holder from E-Mail. -->

  • All the steps will be same, except for the number of parameters passed to the prompt.

 

Prompt variable used -->

iv_targetemailstring --> This will hold the E-mail body in target language which is generated from above step.

iv_salesorderno --> This will contain Sales order number.

lv_lineno --> This will contain all the line-item numbers of Sales order separated by ',' delimiter

lv_material --> This will contain all the material numbers of Sales Order separated by ',' delimiter.

lv_reasnrjn --> This will contain all the rejection reasons for each line in Sales Order separated by ',' delimiter.

Final -Mail Output -->

The E-Mail is translated into the Sold-to Party’s language (French), and all placeholders are replaced with the actual sales order values whenever sales order line items are rejected.

Conclusion 

I hope this post gave you a clear understanding of how to integrate AI into a business scenario using ISLM. Share your thoughts in the comments if you found it helpful.

Useful Links

Local Events --> Working with RAP BO Events end-to-end - Event-driv... - SAP Community

ISLM Overview --> https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=&cad=rja&uact=8&ved=2ahUKEwjoz6KwlO6OAxVyxzgGHW30LSIQFnoECB8QAQ&url=https%3A%2F%2Fhelp.sap.com%2Fdocs%2Fabap-ai%2Fgenerative-ai-in-abap-cloud%2Fabap-ai-sdk-powered-by-intelligent-scenario-lifecycle-management&usg=AOvVaw1NV61P7QjWM68fPchKW_nR&opi=89978449

entry.title: Re: Multi-Input field on RAP Based Fiori Elements Object...
entry.content:
Hello,

The downstream systems are basically retrofitted from prod, but the transport flow is not linear, so the FLP registry doesn’t get reconstructed automatically. intents and target mappings are client dependent so after system copy or retrofit, they don’t show up unless /UI2/FLIA or FLP content activation is explicitly done. so yeah, need to do intent registration manually in the second system.

clear cache after the intents registered:-

/UI2/CHIP_SYNCHRONIZE_CACHE

/UI2/TRANSPORT_UTILS

/UI5/APP_INDEX_CALCULATE

/UI2/INVALIDATE_GLOBAL_CACHES

finally clear browser cache too and check...

Thanks.

entry.title: Re: Update of extension fields in API_MAINTNOTIFICATION
entry.content:
Hello @Kevin46 

Your observation is right to question the creation of a custom API here especially in the context of SAP S/4HANA (Public or Private Cloud) and adherence to clean core principles.

After thoroughly analyzing the API_MAINTNOTIFICATION and associated CDS views (like I_LinearAssetManagementData), I can confirm that MarkerStart and MarkerEnd are not updatable via the standard API, as they are not included in the associated behavior definition (A_MaintenanceNotification).

In alignment with SAP's clean core principles, creating a custom API directly in S/4HANA to enable this functionality would not be advisable. Instead, I recommend two possible clean-core compliant alternatives:

  1. Submit an enhancement request to SAP to include these fields in the updatable payload of the standard API.
  2. Implement a side-by-side extension via SAP BTP using a CAP-based application to handle updates for these fields while consuming the standard API for read operations.

This ensures long-term upgrade compatibility and avoids modifications to the S/4HANA core system.

I hope this helps provide more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: S_P00_07000139 report Issue
entry.content:
Hello @bunty1990 

Thank you for sharing the screenshots and detailed description.

Based on your observations from the S_P00_07000139 report showing different behaviours for the same 261 movement in two plants during REM (Repetitive Manufacturing), the root cause most likely lies in how the cost determination and accounting entries are handled for components consumed via 261 movement, which impacts the Moving Average Price.

My suggestion is to check the following:

  • Price Control (MM03 > Accounting): Ensure it's set to 'V' (Moving Average).
  • Product Cost Collector: Verify it's properly maintained via KKF6N for REM materials.
  • Costing Data: Confirm that cost estimates are released in both plants (CK11N, MM03 > Costing).
  • REM Profile & Backflush Settings: Ensure consistency in production versions (C223).
  • Account Determination: Cross-check OBYC entries for GBB-VBR.
  • Custom Enhancements: Check for any plant-specific BADIs or exits affecting accounting entries.

I hope this helps in providing clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Decimal truncation issue occurred during SAP data mig...
entry.content:
Hi @Navi_Zhang1 

Thank you for raising this point.

The issue you're encountering is due to how Excel handles decimal numbers using IEEE 754 format, which often stores values like "2.93" as "2.92999999999", causing truncation warnings during SAP migration (e.g., DMC_MD_INTERPRETER 37).

Here is my suggested approach:

  1. Use Excel’s ROUND function to limit values to 2 decimal places before uploading:
  2. Insert a helper column with: =ROUND(<OriginalCell>, 2)
  3. Paste the rounded values back as “Values Only” in the original column.
  4. Save and re-upload the file.

Alternatively, if dealing with large files, a script can auto-round decimals across your dataset.

I hope this helps in providing clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to migrate QR-IBAN invoices from Legacy System into S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
You need to migrate QR-IBAN invoices from Legacy system into Public Cloud? 

Follow this step-by-step guide and use Migration Cockpit App to do that!

1. Define Settings for Legacy Data Transfer

In the App Define Settings for Legacy Data Transfer set the Migration Key date and Legacy Data Transfer Status for Company Code:

Define Settings for Legacy Data Transfer

Business Authorisation needed is SAP_BR_CONFIG_EXPERT_DATA_MIG or SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT.

2. Create Migration Project

In the App Migrate Your Data Migration Cockpit (ID F3473) select Create - Migrate Data Using Staging Tables

Step 1:  General Data

Start by naming your migration project:

Enter Project Name

Click on Step 2.

Step 2: Migration Objects

Select migration object "FI- Accounts payable open item" and click on "Review" button.

In the folowing pop up 

Click on "Do Not Add" button. Then, click on "Create Project" button.

The new project is now created and appears in the list:

 

Select your project and go into detail by clicking on arow on the right-hand side.

Select "Download Template":

Download the needed .CSV templates by  "Download Template- Download CSV Files".

3. Upload File

In the detail of your migration project, select "Upload File".

Select "Create CSV folder" and click on button "Create and Open": 

Upload CSV files: Files must be coma delimited and saved as UTF-8 files. The fields marked with "*" are mandatory.

In the BSIK template specify only Vendor line and offsetting account GKONT = 39915000 (initial FI-AP offset account) for the G/L line which will be created automatically on posting. The Amount WRBTR must be specified as a negative value for the Invoice posting. In the field ESRRE specify QR Reference. ISR Number is obsolete.

BSIK Table

In the BSEC template, specify Supplier address data, QR-IBAN in the IBAN field and (optionally) Additional info in the GLO_REF1_OT_CH field.

Note:

Bank Master Data must exists for each QR-IBAN. For example, for QR-IBAN CH4431999123000889012, the bank with the Bank Number 31999 must  already be created in the system.

BSEC Table

Select "Upload"to upload your Files.

4. Mapping and Validations

After uploading, map your files accurately.

Mark the BSEC file and select "Map files", select structure "One-Time Account Data" and press "Map Files".

The Status of One-Time Account Data will change to "Mapped".

Do the same for BSIK file,  and map it to "Supplier Open Items" structure.

When both files are mapped, select "Validate data".

Then,  click on "Show Messages" to check if validation ended without errors.

5. Data Transfer 

Next step is to "Transfer Data to Staging Tables".

By pressing "Show Messages" you can check if transfer ended successfully:

6. Migration preparation

In the Project Detail press "Prepare".

Monitor the preparation status by pressing the button "Monitoring".

7. Mapping Tasks

The next step is "Mapping Tasks".

Confirm Value Mapping.

8. Simulate Migration

In the project detail, select "Simulation" and press button "Start Simulation".

Monitor the simulation status by pressing the button "Monitoring".

9. Migrate

In the project detail, select "Migrate" and press button "Start Migration".

Monitor the migration status by pressing the button "Monitoring".

When the migration ends, check messages and find the number of posted Accounting document:

10. Migration Results

In the project details, select "Migration Results" where you can display and check posted Journal Entry:
Journal Entry

entry.title: Hands-on Tutorial: SAP Databricks
entry.content:
With SAP Databricks we now have a dedicated environment for Data Scientists within the SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog gives a practical introduction to this bespoke Databricks edition by implementing a bare bones demand forecast. SAP Databricks includes important functionality beyond what is explained in this entry-level tutorial., for example data sharing, experiment tracking or AutoML.

The integration of SAP Databricks is adding a new option to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), giving customers more choice when creating custom extensions or applications. Existing components on the BTP, which you might already be familiar with, remain very relevant and strategic, such as:

  • SAP AI Core, which provides for example access to a long list of Large Language Models through its Generative AI Hub. Some of the models are even hosted on SAP's own physical infrastructure, giving increased security (currently Mistral and Aleph Alpha).
  • SAP Document AI, which extracts information from documents such as PDFs, Excel, images, ...
  • SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Datasphere, with their built-in multi-model capabilities, ie Machine Learning, embeddings generation for Text, Vector engine, Graph engine, Geospatial 
  • SAP Build, Joule Studio for adding new skills to our digital assistant Joule, and the ability to create new AI agents on the roadmap. This blog (series) on SAP's AI Agent Architecture by our CTO and Chief AI Officer Philipp Herzig gives an excellent overview of the wider picture.

And remember to check on the AI/ML functionality that has already been built into SAP standard applications, or what is in the pipeline to be released. Both released and planned functionality is shown in the Roadmap Explorer.

Note: All data, code and images that are used in this blog can be downloaded from this repository: Hands-on Tutorial SAP Databricks. In that repository you find the individual files but also the whole project exported as Databricks Archive.

Before we get going, big thanks to Stojan Maleschlijski for all the great collaboration, including exploring the SAP Databricks capabilities together! @stojanm 

 

Table of contents

  • Use Case 
  • Architecture
  • Prerequisites
  • Upload data
  • Explore the data
  • Create a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Schedule a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Good to know
    • Base file
    • Lineage & Table usage insights
    • Visuals
  • Summary

 

Use Case

This blog aims to give a first introduction for carrying out a Machine Learning project on SAP Databricks. Trying to simulate a demand forecast, we will predict how many nights people spend in a hotel in Switzerland. We use some granular data that is kindly shared by the Swiss Statistics department.

A Data Scientist (you) creates a monthly forecast and sets up a schedule for the forecast to be updated every month.  This data would then become part of a business process, maybe you want to provide the data to business users in a dashboard. This tutorial however focusses solely on creating and scheduling the forecast in SAP Databricks.

It's a simple time-series forecasting example, but the concept is still extremely relevant for so many different business requirements. Instead of forecasting how many visitors are staying overnight, you might need to forecast your sales quantities, your cash flow or even for topics that don't come immediately to mind. One customer for instance is using time-series forecasting to improve the data quality of external data that is loaded into the system. If a new value is outside the predicted range, there might be a data quality issue and IT can follow up, whether the data is correct or whether indeed a data quality issue cropped up.

 

Architecture

In a productive system a typical architecture and data flow would look like this.

  1. A Data Product is pushed into the Business Data Cloud Object Store
  2. This Data Product is shared with SAP Databricks
  3. SAP Databricks creates and saves a forecast as DeltaTable into the Object Store
  4. This table is registered as Custom Data Product in the Business Data Cloud
  5. SAP Datasphere installs the Custom Data Product, making it accessible for further data modelling and visualisation in SAP Analytics Cloud

 

The architecture of this hands-on exercise is focused purely on getting some familiarity with SAP Databricks. The only interface we will be using is SAP Databricks. We use it to upload the data and to go through the steps of a Machine Learning project.

 

Prerequisites

Getting started is pretty easy.

  • You will just need to have access to an instance of SAP Databricks. This could be the SAP Business Data Cloud trial.
  • Some familiarity with SQL and especially Python would be very useful. 
  • And maybe just some curiosity to try something new.

 

Upload data

Start by bringing the historic data, on which we want to train a model, into the system. Upload the dataset OVERNIGHTSTAYS.csv with the Graphical User Interface of SAP Databricks. Follow the steps shown in this screencam. In case that you are working with the trial, then you need to change the Catalog drop-down as shown to "workspace".

The data is uploaded. it is showing in the Catalog as (Delta)Table. Physically it is stored in the Object Store. The table's Overview tab lists the column names and their data types:

 

Move to the table's "Sample Data" tab to see some of the uploaded rows.

The first lines shows that in January 2022 there were 392.805 nights spent by Swiss residents in the area of Graubünden. In case you are not that familiar with Swiss geography, Graubünden is the largest Canton in Switzerland, it's in the Alps and includes beautiful places like St. Moritz and Davos. 

 

Explore the data 

You have two options to explore the data in SAP Databricks.

  • Either query the DeltaTable directly with SQL
  • Or use a Notebook, in which you can use both SQL or Python

Data exploration with the SQL Editor

Let's look closer into the data. You can start with some SQL statements. You can go into the SQL Editor and type in your own syntax. The screencam shows two simple examples. We learn for instance that we have data from January 2022 to May 2025 to work with.

  • SELECT * from overnightstays
  • SELECT min(MONTH), max(month) from overnightstays

 

Or describe what you are looking for and have SAP Databrick's write the SQL for you! Click that small red-ish star icon to toggle on the Databricks Assistant.

 

Just try out what you are interested in. I was wondering for example:

  • which regions are in overnightstays?
  • use table overnightstays to determine how many overnight stays were they by region, sort the results
  • use table overnightstays to summarise overnightstays by countryofresidence

 

It turns out that most overnight stays in Switzerland are by Swiss residents, followed by German residents. Maybe surprisingly residents from the United States are a close third.

 

Data exploration with a Notebook

Now continue the data exploration in a Notebook. Databricks Notebooks are quite special in that they can contain more than one scripting language. SAP Databricks supports both SQL as well as Python. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

Begin by creating a folder in which we will save our Notebooks. Go into the "Workspace" section, which is where such files are kept together. Within your user's workspace create a folder called "Demand forecast".

 

In that new folder create a first Notebook as shown in the next screencam. Rename it to "Demand forecast". And add a short header in Markdown at the top. Markdown is a common way to add comments and context to the code in a Notebook. Adding "#" character at the beginning of a line formats the text as top-level heading. Two "#" characters make it a second-level heading, and so on. Without any "#" character the following text is formatted just normally as plain text. 

To add the Markdown, you need to change the cell's language selector to "Markdown" as shown in the screencam. Enter your text. When done, click outside the cell and the formatting kicks in.

 

Since the cells can also execute SQL code, add the most recent SQL statement from the SQL Editor.

SELECT
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE,
  SUM(OVERNIGHTSTAYS) AS total_overnightstays
FROM
  workspace.default.overnightstays
GROUP BY
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE
ORDER BY
  total_overnightstays DESC

 

The screencam shows how a new cell can be added to the Notebook, by hovering with the mouse at the bottom of the cell above. Select "Code" as cell type. Change the cell's language selector to "SQL", paste the code and run it with the blue play button. You will see the same result as before in the "SQL Editor".

 

Let's switch to Python for the data exploration so that you have tried all the options. Create a new Code cell, its language selector might already be on "Python" by default. Begin by loading the data into a PySpark DataFrame using the table's fully qualified path.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Aggregate the data by month and look at the results. The display command initially shows the data as table, but it also comes with a Graphical User interface to quickly create a plot. Follow the steps in the screencam to create a line chart, to see how the numbers have evolved over time. There is a clear pattern, that especially in July and August the numbers are at their highest.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
display(overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays")))

 

Now explore, whether we can visually get a feel for an overall trend in the data, whether the numbers tend to go up or down over time. Have the Assistant do the work of writing the code with this request:

Create a new DataFrame that has the year in a new column. aggregate by year and show the result in a plotly chart

Plotly is a very common Python charting library. And indeed, when looking at the yearly totals, the numbers are increasing for the years.  The year 2025 is not meaningful yet in this chart as the dataset only contains January to May for that year.

 

Create a forecast with SAP Databricks

During the above data exploration we saw that the data has a trend (numbers are increasing over time) and some seasonality (ie numbers are largest in the summer). Let's train a Machine Learning that picks up on such patterns and can estimate future values. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

In case you are unsure about how to implement the following 4 code blocks, then this screencam will guide you along. It shows in a quick scroll through what the output should look like.

 

Read the historic data again into a PySpark DataFrame.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Since we want to create a monthly forecast on the total values, aggregate the history by month. Since we are working with the PySpark DataFrame, the built-in Spark engine is doing the work.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
overnightstaysmonthly_sdf = overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays"))
display(overnightstaysmonthly_sdf)

 

The data needs to be prepared further, so that the Python package called Prophet can train a time-series model on it.

# Convert Spark DataFrame to Pandas DataFrame (the time series algorithm requires a Pandas DataFrame)
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_sdf.toPandas()

# Sort the DataFrame by date
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.sort_values('month')

# Rename the columns, as required by the time-series algoritm Prophet
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.rename(columns={'month': 'ds', 'overnightstays': 'y'})

 

We want to use the Prophet package for the forecast, which still needs to be installed. Here we install it directly from the Notebook. However, in the "Good to know" section below you see a more elegant way of using additional Python package, by creating your own customised Base environment.

pip install prophet==1.1.7

 

Everything is now in place to finally train the time-series model. The following block of code contains multiple steps. It is useful to run these steps together under the "with mlflow.start_run() section as this allows to log information about the training run in SAP Databricks.  The following code:

  • Trains the time series model
  • Creates a DataFrame with the future 12 months that are to be forecasted
  • Creates a forecast for the known past and the future 12 months
  • Calculates  and logs the model's accuracy on the known history
  • Plots and logs the known history against the predicted values
  • Logs the number of records that were used during training

Yes, in a real project this code would be even more elaborate. For example you may want to try different model configurations to get even better forecast accuracy. And the accuracy should ideally be calculated on a hold-out sample. Currently the code uses the same data for training as well as for checking the model's accuracy. The accuracy should really be calculated on data the model has never seen before. 

import pandas as pd
from prophet import Prophet
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_percentage_error
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import mlflow, mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils

mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils._get_registry_uri_from_spark_session = lambda: "databricks-uc"

with mlflow.start_run():

    # Initialize the Prophet model
    model = Prophet()

    # Fit the model
    model.fit(overnightstaysmonthly_df)

    # Create a DataFrame that contains all dates for which a prediction is required, the future 12 months but also the known past for comparison
    datestopredict_df = model.make_future_dataframe(periods=12, freq='MS')

    # Forecast the future and known past
    forecast_df = model.predict(datestopredict_df)

    # Plot the predictions together with known past
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    ax.plot(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat'], label='Forecast', color='red')
    ax.plot(overnightstaysmonthly_df['ds'], overnightstaysmonthly_df['y'], label='Historical Data')
    ax.fill_between(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat_lower'], forecast_df['yhat_upper'], color='red', alpha=0.3)
    ax.set_title('Demand forecast')
    ax.set_xlabel('Month')
    ax.set_ylabel('Total Overnightstays')
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

    # Calculate and log model accuracy, here MAPE on training data
    overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]] = overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]].apply(pd.to_datetime)
    anctualsandpredicted_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df[['ds', 'y']].merge(forecast_df[['ds', 'yhat']], on='ds', how='inner', suffixes=('_left', '_right'))
    prophet_mape = mean_absolute_percentage_error(anctualsandpredicted_df['y'], anctualsandpredicted_df['yhat'])
    mlflow.log_metric("mape", prophet_mape)

    # Log the chart in the Unity Catalog / Experiment
    mlflow.log_figure(fig, "Forecast.png") 

    # Log the size of the training dataset
    mlflow.log_metric("rowcount_training", overnightstaysmonthly_df.shape[0])

 

Run the above code and we see our prediction!

 

To persist the forecast, save it as DeltaTable. From here the data can be made available to SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud. That part is outside the scope of this tutorial, please check the documentation.

forecast_sdf = spark.createDataFrame(forecast_df)
forecast_sdf.write.mode("overwrite").saveAsTable("workspace.default.overnightstays_forecast")

 

The forecast is saved as DeltaTable, that means you can see it in the Catalog!

 

The information that was logged during the training is now available in the Experiments section. The model's MAPE (Median Absolute Percentage Error) is at 1.4%, 41 records were used during training and we can see the chart that compares actuals to predictions. Especially when trying out different settings for the Machine Learning algorithm, this tracking becomes very useful, for instance to select which configuration to use for the prediction.

 

Schedule

Everything we need for our demand forecast is implemented and we can run it manually. That means we are also good to have it automated with a schedule. Straight from the notebook you can define the scheduling logic, ie the recurring interval and whether you want any notifications. The notebooks can also be triggered through APIs if you prefer.

 

Good to know

A few things that might be good to know.

 

Base file

In the above code the Python package Prophet is installed directly from within a Notebook. That's ok, but not ideal for ongoing use. If you were repeatedly re-running all cells from the Notebook, then Python will try to re-install the package every time. It's generally better to centrally specify the packages you know you will be using long term. This also ensures consistency across projects and developers. In SAP Databricks you can specify reusable / shareable lists of Python packages that are to be installed through Base environments.

Create a Base environment by creating a file called base_env_prophet.yaml with this content:

dependencies:
  - prophet==1.1.7

 

With this base file in place, you can

  • Step 1: Remove the pip install command from the "020 Demand forecast" Notebook

 

  • Step 2: Specify that the Notebook will use the base file instead, to determine which packages to install. Here you can also select the Environment version. These are documented here.

 

To test out that the Package is correctly installed through the base file, clear the environment as shown in the screencam and run the Python code in the cells.

 

Lineage & Table usage insights

Now that the table "overnightstays" has been used a few times, check out the lineage, which shows where the table is used and the statistics on how heavily that table is used. 

 

Visuals

From the distance most Notebooks look very much alike at first glance. I heard some great feedback that some visual / image on top of the notebook would help to differentiate. In the repository you find a few examples, in case you would like to use those to distinguish between Data Exploration, AI/ML Sandboxing and AI/ML Deployment.

Upload any images that you want to use into the Workspace. To keep things tidy I am creating a separate folder for them.

 

These images can then be shown in a Markup cell.

 

Summary

SAP Databricks is adding a dedicated Data Science environment to the SAP landscape. After this hands-on experience you hopefully have a first feel for how a Data Scientist can enrich the data in SAP Business Data Cloud with Machine Learning.

For your own projects, you will want to check out the documentation:

  • SAP Databricks documentation by SAP
  • SAP Databricks documentation by Databricks

 

I hope you enjoyed getting hands-on with SAP Databricks!

entry.title: Re: In pricing procedure Statical is not marked as active but still while creating po the indicator
entry.content:
Hi @ab20468864 

Thank you for flagging this.

Upon reviewing the configuration, the issue stems from the Subtotal setting (value 9) for the ZCUS condition type in the ZSEM00 pricing procedure. Even though the “Statistical” checkbox is not enabled, subtotal 9 instructs the system to exclude the condition from the net value calculation, effectively treating it as statistical.

Here is my suggestion:

  • Please update the Subtotal field to blank (or an appropriate value that includes the condition in net value calculation) in the ZSEM00 procedure.
  • No need to change the condition type itself since it behaves correctly in the alternate procedure.

I hope this helps in providing clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in July
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in July

Another month with two great new release deliveries ✨
Learn more in my short top features video in July 2025 on YouTube 📺
In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs.

 

 

My top features in July

 

Data Integration & Connectivity

Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow

After delivering SFTP as a target already in May this year, you can now also use SFTP connections as sources in replication flows to any supported target.

➡️   More information:

  • Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) as Source for Your Replication Flow
  • Generic SFTP Connections

 

Transport Objects Between File Spaces

You can now export objects from and import objects to file spaces, meaning a space based on the embedded object store with file-based artifacts.

➡️   More information

 

Task Chains

New Layout Option in Task Chain Toolbar

The options in the task chain editor toolbar have been re-arranged and a new layout option was added. The new layout option allows you to rearrange the visual display of a task chain on the canvas, from top-to-bottom (the default), or left-to-right.

➡️   More information

 

Connection Type Generic HTTP

With the new connection type, you can connect to external systems and add tasks that are exposed by REST-based APIs to task chains. For this purpose, we have introduced the new API Tasks connection feature, which is supported only for Generic HTTP connections.

➡️   More information

 

Running API Tasks in a Task Chain

The generic HTTP connection is the prerequisite to provide the ability of running tasks in a task chain that use a REST-based API to access external systems.

➡️   More information

 

New Notification Task Object in Task Chains

SAP Datasphere now allows users to set up additional email notification within a task chain, in addition to the notification specified for completion of the entire task chain. Users drag the new Notification Task object to any point in the sequence of tasks run in a task chain and then specify the subject and message for this new email notification. These new notifications use the same recipient list as the email notification maintained at the task chain level.

➡️   More information

 

Self-Service Enhancements

Enable Multi-Availability Zones for SAP HANA Cloud

Use the Enable SAP HANA Multi-Availability Zones option on the Tenant Configuration page to create a synchronous replica of the main system on a system in a different region. The synchronous replica system has a high-availability setup that can take over processing when necessary.

➡️   More information:

  • Configure the Size of Your SAP Datasphere Tenant
  • Creating and Configuring Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

 

Enabling of SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing on Your SAP Datasphere Tenant

Administrators can now create the mapping between their SAP Datasphere tenant and their SAP Business Technology Platform account to enable SAP HANA for SQL data warehousing themselves, rather than needing to raise a ticket. Both environments for Kyma and Cloud Foundry are supported and the same information as previously required for the ticket with Organization ID and Space ID is required to be able to do the instance mapping.

➡️   More information

 

 

 

Webinar Series: Architecting Your SAP BDC Journey – From Data to Intelligence 

There was a great architecture webinar series about SAP Business Data Cloud and various architecture deep dive topics. Thanks to @Gaurish-Dessai, @PaulKurchina, @helmut_grimm and team.

 

Sessions

Speakers

Data Inspired – Successful concepts for data-driven organizations

Paul Kurchina, Dr. Sebastian Wernicke, Helmut Grimm, Gaurish Dessai

Unleash your Data and AI with Irfan Khan and Timo Elliott

Paul Kurchina, Irfan Khan & Timo Elliott

Unpacking SAP Business Data Cloud for Enterprise Architects

Ralph Richter, Gaurish Dessai, Axel Meier, Amogh Umbarkar

Enterprise Architects guide on SAP BW Modernization

Jason Luo & Gaurish Dessai

Planning your Transition Paths to SAP Business Data Cloud

Naveen Dumpa & Jason Luo

SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks – Stronger Together

Michelle Wiktorsson, Qi Su & Habeebuddin Mohammad

SAP Business Data Cloud & Databricks in Action with Demos

Michelle Wiktorsson, Gaurish Dessai, Rithivika Acharya & Peter Schmidt

SAP BDC Series Wrap up – Insights, Learnings, and the Road Ahead

Paul Kurchina, Ralph Richter, Gaurish Desai, Prakash Nanduri & Timo Elliott

Find the session details, slides and recordings here
➡️   Recordings and Slides from webinar series 'Architecting Your SAP Business Data Cloud Journey'

 

Learning Update

The number of learning opportunities are constantly growing and our colleagues in the learning department have delivered the next milestone with a new instructor-led class about SAP Business Data Cloud. Learn more in the blog from @MarkGreen 
➡️   Learn SAP Business Data Cloud with our new instructor-led class

 

Blog series for our Japanese Community

  • SAP Business Data Cloud : SAP Analytics Cloud のプロビジョニング
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) のプロビジョニングガイド
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) 関連情報 まとめブログ
  • SAP Business Data Cloud: オブジェクトストア 入門編
  • SAP Business Data Cloud の概要

 

My favorite blogs in July

This blog describes the next major enhancement of the SAP Datasphere catalog, which is now also enabled to harvest metadata from SAP BW/4HANA. Get all the details in @GaetanSaulnier blog
➡️   SAP Datasphere catalog - Harvesting from SAP BW/4HANA

If you are interested on SAP AI Foundation, SAP BDC and SAP Databricks then check the two blogs from @san_tran below 👇

entry.title: Re: Is there any direct integration available for Power B...
entry.content:
Hello,

Currently there is no direct integration available for Power BI with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we have embedded analytics in the form of SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for analytics & reporting. This analytics is embedded in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and is included in the default licensing of the subscription. You can also connect the Enterprise edition of SAC for further full scope reporting capabilities as required.

If you still want to use the Power BI without the pre-delivered integration, you can consider using CDS views available to OData APIs and consume them as the source of Power BI - Create CDS views in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and consume them as APIs

You can also refer to the below relevant posts from SAP Community for your reference:

  • Is it possible to integrate Power BI with S/4HANA Cloud System?
  • Power BI X S/4HANA Cloud Integration
  • SAP Analytics Cloud and Power BI - A comparison
  • Create CDS views in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and consume them as APIs
  • Connecting Power BI directly to SAP DB #COE # SUPREMECANNABIS
  • POWERBI connection to S/4HANA Cloud public edition
  • Configuring Standard API in S/4 HANA Cloud

For any follow-up questions, you are recommended to go on using SAP Community here. Posting your question to SAP Community will allow it to be seen by a diverse group of individuals, such as Developers, SAP Consultants, Partners, and experienced users, which can lead to more insights and suggestions. This is by far the fastest and easiest way to find solutions to most consulting questions.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: Groovy scrit error when canonicalize XML subtree
entry.content:
Hello @lvanho 

Thank you for the question.

The CPI runtime throws this error because the DOM implementation (DeferredElementNSImpl) provided by SAP CPI isn't compatible with the canonicalize Subtree method from Apache XMLSec.

Here is my suggestion on how to fix this, please switch to using canonicalize operating on a byte array or optionally serialize the XML first and pass it as bytes. Both approaches align with how CPI handles XML and avoid dependency issues seen in the full Java SDK.

I hope this helps in providing clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Consolidated subcontracting PR for multiple productio...
entry.content:
Hello @ramakanth_sagar 

Thank you for your question.

Please note that in the standard SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud or On-Premise), the system generates a separate subcontracting purchase requisition (PR) for each production order. Unfortunately, it is not possible to consolidate these into a single PR across multiple orders using standard functionality. The design ensures that each subcontracting operation is tracked individually, especially for planning and traceability.

That been said, PRs can be consolidated into one purchase order during the conversion stage, provided the vendor and the purchasing data align. In this case, if PR-level consolidation is a strict requirement, a custom enhancement would be necessary to modify how PRs are created or grouped.

I hope this helps in providing clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Use Selected Period from Pipeline Run in Backend (SAP...
entry.content:
Hello Sayyid,

when configuring your stage hooks that call the stored procedure, you can specify input parameters. For example, a stage hook descriptor for the Pre Allocate phase could look like this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<stagehooks version="1.0">
   <stagehook stagename="Allocate">
      <prestage type="storedproc">
         <command>EXT.Pre_Allocate</command>
         <pipelineArgs>
            <name>stage</name>
            <name>period</name>
            <name>periodSeq</name>
            ... additional Parameters ...
         </pipelineArgs>
      </prestage>
      </stagehook>
</stagehooks>
 
You can then access these arguments in your stored procedure as input parameters and use them in your code:
 
CREATE PROCEDURE EXT.PRE_ALLOCATE (
    IN i_stage VARCHAR(255),
    IN i_period VARCHAR(255) DEFAULT null,
    IN i_periodSeq bigint DEFAULT null,
    ... additional Parameters ...
) DEFAULT SCHEMA EXT
AS
BEGIN
...Your code...
END​

Kind regards,

Maximilian

entry.title: Electronic Document Processing for Italy: Avoid Issues During Migration from Neo to Cloud Foundry
entry.content:
Migrating your system from Neo environment to Cloud Foundry environment to continue using electronic document processing for Italy after 2025 can be a complex process, especially when dealing with custom domains and Cloud Integration tenant applications. One critical prerequisite that often poses challenges is ensuring that both test and production tenants are on the same system landscape. 

Here you find what you need to know to prepare for what you can do to make this process smoother. 

Understanding Landscapes 

A landscape refers to the environment where your applications and services are hosted. It can be a normal landscape or an extension landscape. To determine if your tenant is on an extension landscape, check the URL. For instance, a URL like "https://tenantname.cfapps.eu10-003.hana.ondemand.com/itspaces" indicates an extension landscape due to the "-003" in the URL. For more information, see Extension Landscapes. 

Importance of Matching System Landscapes 

For a successful setup, both the custom domain and cloud integration tenant must reside on the same landscape. If they aren't on the same landscape, the setup fails. This requires you to work on an additional step of reprovisioning the tenants. For example, a mismatch occurs if the custom domain is on the cf-eu12 landscape while the tenant is on the cf-eu12-001 landscape. 

Mitigating Risks 

To minimize the risk of mismatched landscapes, you should request a test and a production tenant simultaneously. This approach reduces the chance of being provisioned to different extension landscapes. Before developing any content, it's crucial to verify that the domains of both tenants align. 

By taking these precautions, you can ensure a smoother migration process and avoid unnecessary complications. Remember, a little foresight can save a lot of time and effort down the road. 

Steps for Migration 

You can find more information about how to migrate electronic document processing for Italy FatturaPA and B2B from Neo to Cloud Foundry environment on SAP Note 2583309. 

 

Thanks for reading! 

Got any questions or feedback? Please leave a comment below or give feedback about the product assistance directly on the SAP Help Portal by using the comments feature. 

 

See you next time, 

Ailane Kuhn

#SAPGoGlobal #SAPLocalization

entry.title: Re: PO Subtotal Mismatch in Ariba — Request to Fix via Ad...
entry.content:
Hi @Napop 

Thanks for highlighting the issue.

The discrepancy between ERP and Ariba subtotals arises because Ariba currently only receives the Quantity and Unit Price fields but not the actual Net Amount after discounts or pricing conditions from ERP.

Yes, it is possible. To resolve this, send the actual net amount to Ariba. This can be achieved by enabling the ERP-to-Ariba integration mapping for the Net Value field using SAP Ariba Cloud Integration Gateway (CIG) or middleware iFlows.

To achieve this, you will need to:

  1. Ensure your ERP PO output includes the net value per line item.
  2. Adjust the outbound mapping (typically via cXML or IDoc) to pass the net amount explicitly.
  3. Verify that Ariba is configured to consume and display the NetAmount under “Subtotal”.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Email signatures in Successfactors
entry.content:
Hello @MelanieBorcher 

Thank you for reaching out.

Your observation is right. In SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, the ‘Contact’ feature primarily supports tokens like Recruiter Name and Company Logo, but it doesn’t natively support inserting a full custom email signature per user directly in the UI.

Here are a few current options:

  1. Manual Workaround: You can manually paste your full email signature into the message body when composing emails to candidates.
  2. Template Enhancement: If you're using email templates, an admin can include a static signature block at the bottom of the template, though this is not personalized per recruiter.
  3. Custom Token Option (Advanced): With help from your system administrator, it may be possible to create custom tokens via Business Rules or MDF objects but this would require some configuration and may not be practical for all users.

Unfortunately, user-specific dynamic signatures are not supported out of the box as of the current SAP Public Cloud SuccessFactors release.

Many customers have voiced similar feedback. You might also consider submitting this as an Improvement Request on the SAP Customer Influence and Adoption Portal.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Cloud Integration - What You Need to Know About the Kafka Adapter
entry.content:
There is no particular batch message to pass to the adapter. The adapter will forward messages to the broker going to the same partition (if batching is enabled), if they reach the same receiver adapter "around the same time frame". The intention is to save roundtrips to enable high throughput in high volume scenarios. So in a normal case, you'd not worry about lingering. The adapter would try to figure out by itself, when to send a batch (or single message) depending on load. The linger time enables you to artificially add a waiting time frame for additional records to reach the adapter before sending out a batch, i.e. you can delay it manually.

And within this time frame, you need to reach the adapter several times (i.e. in parallel). Either by sending messages in parallel to this integration flow, or by other means (like a parallel splitter, which comes with its own consequences, so I am not suggesting anything here). But if you split messages "in sequence", then the sequence only ends when the split-gather routine ends. And if the kafka adapter is within this route, then the adapter is not finished when it is reached, but when the batch was sent out.

Best regards

Jens

entry.title: SAP Community Escape House for August - Fiori Element with Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
The eighth edition of the SAP Developer Challenge 2025 has officially kicked off!  A brand-new room has opened its doors inside the SAP Community Escape House.  Hope you all escaped alive from the SAP Application Event Hub room last month. 

In this developer challenge, we are focusing on SAP Fiori Element and the Flexible Programming Model. We are going to cover topics like:

FPM - Extension Points

FPM - Building Block

FPM - Controller Extension

 

Prerequisite

You have to clone the repository from:

https://github.com/SAP-samples/fiori-elements-fpm-exercises-codejam.git

For this challenge, you will be working in the finished-bookshop folder. This folder contains a completed CAP project that serves as the starting point for exploring extensibility using the Flexible Programming Model with SAP Fiori Elements.

All extension tasks, including UI enhancements and controller customizations, will be implemented on top of this CAP project. Inside this project, there is an existing Fiori Elements List Report application named bookshop-ui, which serves as the foundation for this challenge.

You will extend this application using the Flexible Programming Model, applying techniques such as Fiori extension points, building blocks, and controller extensions to tailor the UI and behavior according to developer challenge.

 

How to participate

Visit the SAP Community Escape House and enter your numeric SAP Community user ID.

SAP Community Escape House

If you're unsure of your user ID, you can find it on your user settings page url.

1. Goto SAP Community Page

2. Click on Account and then select My content. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

3. You can find the community user ID in the web page URL. 

Once you see the SAP Community Escape House, select the SAP Fiori Element room and start exploring it.

 

The user interface of an escape room includes the room itself as well as a terminal. You can click the objects in the room to receive tips. Like in a real (physical) escape room, you will have to try out a few things and explore the room until you receive helpful tips and, eventually, instructions. These tips and instructions are printed in the terminal next to the room. The terminal is also used to submit solutions to tasks. Read the instructions you receive carefully to understand how.

If you successfully escape the room (you will know when that happens), you will receive a badge in the SAP Community. We will assign the badges once the challenge closes.

 

The schedule

The SAP Fiori room will be unlocked on August 4th and will stay unlocked until the end of the year. However, the challenge closes on August 31st, so you must escape the room until then to qualify for a badge. Unlike the previous year, this SAP Developer Challenge does not consist of weekly sub-challenges. The next room (next challenge) will be unlocked in September.

 

Useful links for the challenge

  • Flexible Programming Model : https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/test-resources/sap/fe/core/fpmExplorer/index.html#/overview/introduction
  • Fiori Element OData V4 : https://developers.sap.com/group.fiori-tools-odata-v4-incident.html
  • FPM Code Jam : https://github.com/SAP-samples/fiori-elements-fpm-exercises-codejam/tree/main?tab=readme-ov-file

Good luck and happy escaping!

entry.title: Re: Multi-Tenant Audit Logging Fails for Subscriber Tenan...
entry.content:
Hi @agustino 

Hope you're doing well.

Thank you for your detailed questions. Let me walk you through it.

Following up on the audit logging issue, the 401 Unauthorized error you're seeing for subscriber tenants is expected behaviour when you use the Audit Log Service bound only to the provider tenant. This configuration works fine for the provider, but subscriber tenants lack the necessary credentials unless specific steps are taken.

Here’s a quick summary of the findings and options:

The audit log service isn't accessible to subscribers because it's not bound to their tenant context. The token issued doesn't carry valid client credentials for the logging API.

I suggest you do the following:

Ensure to use centralized audit logging in the provider tenant, while passing the subscriber context (.tenant($SUBSCRIBER)) when logging events. This is the SAP-recommended approach for multi-tenant CAP apps.

Alternatively, you can create and bind separate audit log service instances per subscriber. This will enable full isolation but is less scalable.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508: AI-Enabled and Innovative Master Data Governance
entry.content:
Introduction

The image below shows the main product versions of SAP Master Data Governance and the context they are primarily used in. This blog post covers the latest innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, master data governance (shown in the center of the graphic). 

SAP Master Data Governance product versions

Companies that are moving to or already run on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition and seek to govern their business partner or product data to control key master data processes across the enterprise can now benefit from top notch innovations that come with the latest public cloud version of SAP Master Data Governance: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, master data governance, release 2508 provides new and enhanced features in the areas of AI-enablement, central governance including inbound data integration for decentral maintenance scenarios, master data consolidation, and data quality management for enterprise-wide master data management, plus mass load and maintenance capabilities for local use of product and business partner data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The focus in this release is clearly on the governance in the business partner domain (central governance to put it precisely), but there are still some enhancements in the bag for governing product data. Let me give you more innovation details per area.

Overview of capabilities and indication of new/revamped features for governing business partner data

AI Enablement

AI support in master data processing of business partner and product data has been enabled with a specific focus on increased usability and effectiveness for specific roles. Accordingly:

  • Master data stewards and specialists can now use embedded AI in the key master data processes for business partner and product and benefit from easy filtering to find information using natural language. This way, even experienced master data stewards benefit from increased speed and ease of use in master data processing.
  • Any user who needs to access business partner can benefit from embedded AI filtering for data prompts in natural language.

Search in natrual language with AI-based filtering

Note: The use of the generative AI copilot Joule for business users to display core business partner data in central governance is planned to come prior to the 2602 release, as outlined in SAP Roadmap Explorer.​

For more information about the role of AI in master data governance and the impact of master data governance for AI, you may read this blog post. 

Central Governance

The enabling of central governance for business partner data  is a cornerstone for an enterprise-wide master data management approach with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, master data governance.

Central creation of a business partner

This is a key capability required for proactive master data management because it ensures data consistency at the point of creation or change (in contrast to reactive consolidation).

SOAP-based inbound data integration for de-central scenarios

Central governance also includes decentral scenarios with integrated inbound processing where the initial data entry (creation or change) is made in a decentral application.

In addition, it features quick process insight through the visualization of the change approval status.

Visualization of change approval status in central governance

In addition to the AI-enabled functions outlined above, central governance for business partner also features increased automation in master data processing through data provider integration and derivation scenarios, both used and designed for auto-populating fields with high-quality data. 

Defining derivation scenario for automated field population

In short, AI-driven and highly automated central governance (including decentral maintenance scenarios) is essential for comprehensive, future-geared master data management across the enterprise.

Please note that central governance for product data is on the roadmap. 

Master Data Consolidation

Best-record calculation

Master data consolidation is all about central activities involved in the de-duplication of de-centrally managed master data. In master data consolidation for business partner, we have significantly increased usability and effectiveness. This includes, for example:

  • Configuration options from workflow to end-to-end automation of processes ​
  • Inclusion of attachments for all processes​
  • Maintenance of process-related data such as description, priority, reason, and due date​
  • Process visualization for clear insight into the current processing status​

Data Quality Management

Data quality evaluation (business partner data)

Data quality management enables master data stewards to get and keep key master data clean. It gives them a handle to define, enforce, monitor, and improve the quality of business partner and product data based on a rule repository and related data quality evaluations​. We have increased the usability and effectiveness, for example, by enabling derivation scenarios to automate the creation and updating of business partner and product data, and by an improved process flow in the creation and maintenance of validation rules.

Mass Load and Mass Maintenance

Mass maintenance of business partner

This capability allows you to process master data from uploaded files and make changes to large amounts of business partner and product data for local use. It does not require an extra license and is suited for local maintenance only. The innovations for mass load and mass maintenance specified in the next chapter apply. 

In a Nutshell: New and Revamped Apps for Business Partner Processes

As you can see, the main innovation focus of master data governance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 is on the business partner domain. In a nutshell, the new and revamped apps for business partner processes (as shown in the image above) have the following benefits:

  • Enable a consumer-grade user experience across all processes via consistent process and UI design, across all MDG processes
  • Allow end-to-end automation and workflow for all relevant processes, including consolidation and mass processing
  • Provide direct editing within mass processing UI (spreadsheet-like UI) for any process step
  • Allow seamless navigation between mass processing and single processing UIs for data maintenance​

For more information about the individual apps and their implementation, see:

  • SAP Help Portal documentation about Successor apps for mass load and mass maintenance of business partners​
  • SAP Help Portal documentation about Successor apps for governing business partner data

As pointed out before, major revamping of the product domain including the introduction of central governance is on the roadmap.

Find out more...

I hope this is good news for you when you are planning to start or increase your master data management initiatives on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. As pointed out before, more innovations, such as persona-based AI features in master data governance processes and more domain coverage (i. e. product) are planned on the roadmap.

For a complete functional overview of the MDG capabilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2508, see the overview presentation and the documentation on SAP Help Portal.

To stay on track, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance, read the MDG-related blogs, and join the  Q&A forum.

Best,

Markus

​​

​
